query: Analyze electric vehicle adoption policies in emerging markets. Compare incentive structures, charging infrastructure plans, and manufacturing policies in India, Brazil, South Africa, and Indonesia. Include policy timelines and market penetration data. Map solar facilities across India, Brazil, and South Africa to show renewable energy infrastructure supporting EV charging.

nodes.label: impacted workers
nodes.description: Working people who are disproportionately impacted by climate change or the response to climate change

nodes.label: active labour market policies
nodes.description: Government programmes that intervene in the labour market to help the unemployed find work, but also for the underemployed and employees looking for better jobs.

nodes.label: green workplace
nodes.description: A workplace that is environmentally sensitive, resource efficient, and socially responsible.

nodes.label: zero-emission vehicle standard
nodes.description: Zero-emission vehicle standards require vehicle sellers to achieve minimum requirements for sales of zero-emission vehicles in the jurisdiction.

nodes.label: just transition
nodes.description: Broadly defined as ensuring that no one is left behind or pushed behind in the transition to low-carbon.

nodes.label: public-private partnership
nodes.description: A public–private partnership is a long-term arrangement between a government and private sector institutions.

nodes.label: employable skills
nodes.description: Refer to a set of transferable skills and key personal attributes which are highly valued by employers and essential for effective performance in the workplace.

nodes.label: informal workers
nodes.description: Informal workers do not have secure employment contracts, workers' benefits, social protection or workers' representation

nodes.label: critical infrastructure failure
nodes.description: Critical Infrastructure failure is defined as the failure in one or more of the physical structures, facilities, networks and other assets which provide services that are essential to the social and economic functioning of a community or society.

nodes.label: skills needs assessment
nodes.description: Activities to assess future skills needs in the labour market in a strategic way, using consistent and systematic methods.

nodes.label: green job
nodes.description: Jobs that contribute to preserving or restoring the environment, both in traditional sectors (manufacturing and construction) or in new emerging ‘green’ sectors, such as renewable energy and energy efficiency

nodes.label: mitigation
nodes.description: Reducing the emission of and quantity of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. This involves cutting emissions from "sources" of greenhouse gases e.g. petrol cars and enhancing "sinks" which draw emissions down from the atmosphere e.g. forests.

nodes.label: adaptation
nodes.description: The process of adjusting to living in a changing climate. This can include altering behaviour, systems, and ways of life to reduce or avoid both current and future harms from climate impacts.

nodes.label: energy efficiency standard
nodes.description: Energy efficiency standards are government regulations that set a minimum level of energy performance for buildings or appliances, typically measured by an energy rating scale (like A-G), meaning that products or properties must meet a certain level of efficiency to be sold or rented, aiming to reduce energy consumption and carbon emissions; in practice, this often means landlords must ensure their rental properties reach a minimum energy efficiency rating.

nodes.label: infrastructure investment
nodes.description: Public funding of infrastructure investments is the use of money from the public sector to fund physical assets that support a country's development.

nodes.label: peer learning
nodes.description: Peer learning is essentially the act of learning with and from your colleagues, fellow students or peers.

nodes.label: electricity distribution sector
nodes.description: Sector involving the delivery of electricity from high-voltage transmission lines to end users at lower voltages through a network of local power lines and transformers

nodes.label: labour principle
nodes.description: International labour standards on a broad range of subjects related to the world of work, including human rights at work, employment policy and human resources development.

nodes.label: decent work
nodes.description: Work that provides adequate wages, safe working conditions, workers’ rights, social dialogue and social protection.

nodes.label: welfare activities
nodes.description: Support services provided by a range of actors, including but not limited to the state.

nodes.label: workforce
nodes.description: The people engaged in or available for work, either in a country or area or in a particular firm or industry.

nodes.label: workers impacted by the transition
nodes.description: People whose job is at risk due to the societal changes necessary to respond to climate change

nodes.label: job loss
nodes.description: A situation in which people lose their jobs.

nodes.label: tax incentive
nodes.description: Tax incentives reduce tax liabilities to promote environmentally beneficial investments and behaviours.

nodes.label: social inclusion
nodes.description: Social inclusion is the process of improving the terms on which individuals and groups take part in society—improving the ability, opportunity, and dignity of those disadvantaged on the basis of their identity.

nodes.label: social partners
nodes.description: Representatives of management and labour (employer organisations and trade unions), and in some contexts public authorities, that engage in social dialogue.

nodes.label: skills recognition
nodes.description: Skills recognition is a process that formally recognises and acknowledgement the skills you have learned from your work, life experiences, or from any previous training.

nodes.label: vocational rehabilitation
nodes.description: Services aimed at helping individuals reintegrate into the workforce and engage with their communities

nodes.label: green entrepreneurship
nodes.description: Green entrepreneurship is a particular subset of entrepreneurship that focuses on developing and putting into practice solutions to environmental issues as well as encouraging social change to prevent ecological damage.

nodes.label: labour market information
nodes.description: Labour market information is any information that assists people in making informed decisions about the labour market.

nodes.label: renewable portfolio standard
nodes.description: Renewable Portfolio Standards (RPS) require that a minimum percentage of electricity is generated from specified renewable sources.

nodes.label: resource allocation
nodes.description: Resource allocation is the assignment of available resources to various uses.

nodes.label: hydroelectric energy generation
nodes.description: generation of electricity using water as a renewable energy source, including hydropower plants and tidal energy systems

nodes.label: trade unions
nodes.description: An organized association of workers in a trade, group of trades, or profession, formed to protect and further their rights and interests.

nodes.label: economic dislocation
nodes.description: Economic dislocations, whether due to natural disasters, civil disruption, influx of refugees or regional warfare, distort economic projections and necessitate the diversion of resources from planned development programmes.

nodes.label: job creation
nodes.description: The provision of new opportunities for paid employment, especially for those who are unemployed.

nodes.label: electricity failure
nodes.description: A loss of power for a short period of time, often caused by technological failure and extreme weather events

nodes.label: job training
nodes.description: Structured process of providing employees with the knowledge and skills needed for their current or future roles.

nodes.label: livelihood
nodes.description: A means of supporting one's existence, especially financially or vocationally.

nodes.label: public participation
nodes.description: Any process that involves the public in problem-solving or decision-making and that uses public input to make better decisions.

nodes.label: social justice
nodes.description: Justice in terms of the distribution of wealth, opportunities, and privileges within a society.

nodes.label: Runoff control structures
nodes.description: Runoff control structures are designed to capture runoff during peak flows, and can function as temporary storage sites. These structures are typically built with a discharge component to slowly release water into the nearby waterway to avoid it overflowing from the storage basin. It can be artificially built, for example by excavating a large area so that it is lower than the surrounding land.

nodes.label: skills development
nodes.description: Acquiring, improving or enhancing a wide range of knowledge, expertise, and capabilities

nodes.label: green technology
nodes.description: The use of technology and science to reduce human impacts on the natural environment.

nodes.label: market-rate debt
nodes.description: Loans offered at prevailing market interest rates for financing projects

nodes.label: Solar water distillation
nodes.description: Solar water distillation is the process of using the energy from sunlight to separate freshwater from salts or other contaminants.

nodes.label: occupational safety and health
nodes.description: The anticipation, recognition, evaluation and control of hazards arising in or from the workplace that could impair the health and well-being of workers.

nodes.label: employer
nodes.description: A person or organization that employs people.

nodes.label: social dialogue
nodes.description: Social dialogue means concrete actions from its key stakeholders – governments, workers' and employers' organizations – as well as from the involved social dialogue institutions at all levels.

nodes.label: manufacturing sector
nodes.description: The activities of industries that transforms raw materials into finished goods through industrial processes.

nodes.label: labour council
nodes.description: An association of labour unions or union branches in a given area. Most commonly, they represent unions in a given geographical area, whether at the district, city, region, or provincial or state level.

nodes.label: workers' rights
nodes.description: Workers’ rights encompass a large array of human rights from the right to decent work and freedom of association to equal opportunity and protection against discrimination or specific rights related to the workplace.

nodes.label: income security
nodes.description: Having an adequate level of income, but also assurances and expectations about receiving an income now and in the future.

nodes.label: electric power production
nodes.description: process of generating electricity from various energy sources, such as fossil fuels, nuclear power, and renewables

nodes.label: employment opportunities
nodes.description: Employment opportunities refer to potential job prospects or chances for individuals to secure employment in various fields.

nodes.label: data breach
nodes.description: A data breach is a compromise of security that leads to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to protected data transmitted, stored, or otherwise processed.

nodes.label: policy instruments
nodes.description: Policy instruments are techniques or tools used by governing authorities to promote certain policies in order to achieve predetermined goals. Put simply, instruments are how a government tries to achieve its goals.

nodes.label: technical education
nodes.description: Focuses on teaching students the skills and knowledge needed to succeed in technical or vocational fields. It is designed to provide students with practical, hands-on learning experiences that can be directly applied to the modern workforce.

nodes.label: supply and demand
nodes.description: The amount of a commodity, product, or service available and the desire of buyers for it, considered as factors regulating its price.

nodes.label: training system
nodes.description: A training system is a group or family of coursework that will achieve a stated series of training objectives. A training system typically employs a syllabus or similar document that specifies and outlines the coursework to be followed.

nodes.label: social protection
nodes.description: Social protection is concerned with preventing, managing, and overcoming situations that adversely affect people's well-being.

relationships.formatted: impacted workers -> workers impacted by the transition (HAS_SUBCONCEPT)
active labour market policies -> just transition (SUBCONCEPT_OF)
just transition -> active labour market policies (HAS_SUBCONCEPT)
just transition -> occupational safety and health (HAS_SUBCONCEPT)
just transition -> workers impacted by the transition (HAS_SUBCONCEPT)
welfare activities -> workers impacted by the transition (RELATED_TO)
workers impacted by the transition -> impacted workers (SUBCONCEPT_OF)
workers impacted by the transition -> just transition (SUBCONCEPT_OF)
workers impacted by the transition -> welfare activities (RELATED_TO)
occupational safety and health -> just transition (SUBCONCEPT_OF)

kg_data.query: Analyze electric vehicle adoption policies in emerging markets. Compare incentive structures, charging infrastructure plans, and manufacturing policies in India, Brazil, South Africa, and Indonesia. Include policy timelines and market penetration data. Map solar facilities across India, Brazil, and South Africa to show renewable energy infrastructure supporting EV charging.
